title: New ramp signals installed on Australia’s Bruce Highway to ease congestion
text:
New ramp signals installed on Australia’s Bruce Highway to ease congestion 22 September 2015 Print Email 
The newly installed ramp signals and electronic communications on the Bruce Highway between Caboolture and the Pine River in Queensland, Australia, is slated to be activated next week to help improve traffic flows at key congestion points. 
The equipment was installed as part of the $34.8m Bruce Highway Managed Motorways project, which falls under the Australian Government's action plan to fix the Bruce Highway. 
The project covers deployment of a suite of smart technologies to maximise capacity in peak periods, whilst also improving travel times and boosting driver safety. "Keeping the Bruce Highway moving is a key part of improving local lifestyles and boosting the local economy." 
Australia's Deputy Prime Minister and Infrastructure and Regional Development Minister Warren Truss said the new signals used smart technology to detect and manage vehicle merge sections of the highway. 
The ramp signals will play the same role as traffic lights and are scheduled to be operated only operate during high-demand periods such as the morning peak-hours. 
In particular, the signals will control the number of vehicles entering the highway from Dohles Rocks Road, Anzac Avenue, Boundary Road, Deception Bay Road and Uhlmann Road on-ramps. 
Petrie federal member Luke Howarth said: "They will certainly help reduce stop-start travel and manage congestion on the Bruce Highway between the Gateway Motorway and Caboolture until longer-term solutions are implemented." 
The equipment will undergo some modifications for timing and coordination during the first few months of operation, to help motorists adjust to the new technology. 
Additional project works on the Bruce Highway between Caboolture and the Pine River are expected to be investigated in early 2016. 
Longman member Wyatt Roy said: "Congestion not only costs commuters time with their families, it also has significant costs for our freight industry. 
"Keeping the Bruce Highway moving is a key part of improving local lifestyles and boosting the local economy." 
The Bruce Highway Managed Motorways project is jointly funded by the Australian and Queensland Governments on a 50:50 basis.
